brief_description of the content in the: The source URL from JetBrains provides information about an inspection that reports if an @AspectJ argNames attribute value does not correspond to the actual method parameter name. This is a common issue in Aspect Oriented Programming (AOP) where the argNames attribute in an advice annotation does not match the actual parameter names in the method signature.
generated_rule_explanation from GPT-4: The rule 'advice_argNames_consistency_check' checks all classes and their methods. If a method has an @AspectJ annotation, it retrieves the 'argNames' attribute from the annotation. If the 'argNames' attribute is not empty, it asserts that there exists a parameter name in the method's parameter names that matches the 'argNames' attribute. If the assertion fails, it generates a message indicating that the 'argNames' attribute does not correspond to the actual method parameter name.
PRE_model_validation: The generated rule is valid according to the syntax of RSL and the content addressed in the JetBrains web page. It uses only the built-in functions and does not introduce any new ones. The rule checks for the consistency between the 'argNames' attribute in an @AspectJ annotation and the actual parameter names in the method, which is the topic addressed in the JetBrains web page.
